2 **PROGRESS** library. LA-UR number **LA-UR-17-27372**

24 A library for quantum chemistry solvers
25 =======================================
26 
27 **PROGRESS**: Parallel, Rapid **O(N)** and Graph-based Recursive Electronic
28 Structure Solver. **LA-CC-16-068**
29 
30 - This library is focused on the development of general solvers that are
31  commonly used in **quantum chemistry packages**.
32 
33 - This library has to be compiled with the `Basic Matrix Library (BML)
34  <https://basic-matrix-library.readthedocs.io/en/latest/>`_.
35 
36 - Our webpage can be found at https://qmd-progress.readthedocs.io/
37

61 
62 Build Dependencies
63 ==================
64 
65 - **>=OpenMP-3.1**
66 - **>=metis-5.0** if building with **PROGRESS_GRAPHLIB**
67 
68 Note that on some distributions, metis is available as a package. Make sure you
69 install the **-dev** package. For example, Ubuntu requires **libmetis-dev**.
70 
71 Testing in our CI container
72 ===========================
73 
74 We are switching our CI tests from Travis-CI to GitHub Actions because Travis-CI
75 is `limiting the number of builds for open source projects
76 <https://blog.travis-ci.com/2020-11-02-travis-ci-new-billing>`_. Our workflow
77 uses a
78 `custom Docker image <https://hub.docker.com/r/nicolasbock/qmd-progress>`_ which
79 comes with the necessary compiler tool chain and a pre-installed `bml` library
80 to build and test the **qmd-progress** library. Using **docker** is a convenient
81 and quick way to develop, build, and test the **qmd-progress** library.
82 
83 .. code-block:: console
84 
85  ./scripts/run-local-docker-container.sh
86 
87 Inside the container:
88 
89 .. code-block:: console
90 
91  ./build.sh compile
92 
93 Alternatively, you can run one of the CI tests by executing e.g.
94 
95 .. code-block:: console
96 
97  ./scripts/ci-with-graphlib-debug.sh
98 
99 Build and Install Instructions
100 ==============================
101 
102 How to build
103 ------------
104 
105 .. code-block:: console
106 
107  CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=<BML install path> ./build.sh
108 
109 How to install
110 --------------
111 
112 .. code-block:: console
113 
114  cd build
115  sudo make install
116 
117 To specify the Intel Fortran compiler:
118 
119 .. code-block:: console
120 
121  FC=ifort PKG_CONFIG_PATH=<BML install path>/lib/pkgconfig ./build.sh
122 
123 To build with the gfortran compiler and OpenMP:
124 
125 .. code-block:: console
126 
127  CC=gcc FC=gfortran \
128  CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
129  PROGRESS_OPENMP=yes \
130  CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=<BML install path> \
131  CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<PROGRESS install path> \
132  ./build.sh configure
133 
134 To build with OpenMP, MPI and testing enabled:
135 
136 .. code-block:: console
137 
138  CC=mpicc FC=mpif90 \
139  CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
140  PROGRESS_OPENMP=yes \
141  PROGRESS_MPI=yes \
142  PROGRESS_TESTING=yes \
143  CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=<BML install path> \
144  CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<PROGRESS install path> \
145  ./build.sh configure
146 
147 To build with OpenMP, MPI, testing enabled and example programs built:
148 
149 .. code-block:: console
150 
151  CC=mpicc FC=mpif90 \
152  CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
153  PROGRESS_OPENMP=yes \
154  PROGRESS_MPI=yes \
155  PROGRESS_TESTING=yes \
156  PROGRESS_EXAMPLES=yes \
157  CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=<BML install path> \
158  CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<PROGRESS install path> \
159  ./build.sh configure
160 
161 To build with OpenMP and MPI and testing enabled and example programs built
162 and the METIS graph partitioning library:
163 
164 .. code-block:: console
165 
166  CC=mpicc FC=mpif90 \
167  CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
168  PROGRESS_OPENMP=yes \
169  PROGRESS_MPI=yes \
170  PROGRESS_GRAPHLIB=yes \
171  PROGRESS_TESTING=yes \
172  PROGRESS_EXAMPLES=yes \
173  CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=<BML install path> \
174  CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<PROGRESS install path> \
175  ./build.sh configure
176

195 Support acknowledges
196 ====================
197 
198 This development is currently supported by the Exascale Computing Project
199 (17-SC-20-SC), a collaborative effort of two U.S. Department of Energy
200 organizations (Office of Science and the National Nuclear Security
201 Administration) responsible for the planning and preparation of a capable
202 exascale ecosystem, including software, applications, hardware, advanced system
203 engineering, and early testbed platforms, in support of the nation’s exascale
204 computing imperative.
205 
206 Basic Energy Sciences (LANL2014E8AN) and the Laboratory Directed Research and
207 Development Program of Los Alamos National Laboratory. To tests these
208 developments we used resources provided by the Los Alamos National Laboratory
209 Institutional Computing Program, which is supported by the U.S. Department of
210 Energy National Nuclear Security Administration
